keyTakeAways: At least 44 people have died in central and southeastern Mexico due to torrential rains from tropical storms, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting a higher toll of 48.

The flooding was caused by heavy downpours from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which affected multiple states including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí.
Fatalities were distributed as 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and around 320,000 people have suffered power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The government mobilized the military to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, emphasizing a national commitment to humanitarian response.
Photos from military operations show evacuation efforts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high floodwaters.
Mexico has experienced unusually heavy rains this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades, indicating a broader climate trend.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have triggered severe flooding and landslides across central and southeastern Mexico, including the states of Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí. The death toll has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal citing 48 fatalities and dozens still missing. Around 320,000 people have lost power, and 16,000 homes have been damaged. President Claudia Sheinbaum deployed the military to conduct evacuations and deliver aid, emphasizing the government’s commitment to saving lives and providing support. The event underscores the vulnerability of Mexico to extreme weather, especially in light of unusually heavy rainfall in recent months, including Mexico City’s rainiest June in over two decades.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
